_exec_summary.SummaryText:
AFG Industries, Inc.  Taylor County, West Virginia

The Jerry Run Flat Glass manufacturing facility began operation at it current location in 1975.  With the exception of some minor modifications this 650 ton per day of glass production facility operates as originally started up in 1975.  The only 112r listed material stores at the facility in quantities above trigger levels is sulfur dioxide which is received in low pressure one (1) ton cylinders (Maximum of six (6) cylinders).  AFG also utilizes 150  pound cylinders of sulfur dioxide for another portion of the process.  The maximum number of 150 pound cylinders of sulfur dioxide on site is four (4).   No flammables or below threshold 112r materials have the potential to travel to an endpoint beyond the plant boundary (460)  feet from storage area to plant boundary) under winds of 1.5 meters/second.
For the Sulfur Dioxide (SO2) which would be released as a gas, the endpoint for a worst case scenario  under winds of 1.5 meters/second with two (2) entire 2000 lb. cylinders released over a ten minute period is 3.1 miles. The alternate scenario is a release of 60 pounds over a one hour period.  Sixty pounds per hour is the most gas, which can be released as the result of a failure of the regulator for the cylinder or the piping between the cylinder and the manifold.  A sixty (60) pounds per hour release has a end point of <0.1 miles from the source and therefore will not result as an off site impact.  The nearest residential area is 0.8 miles from the plant boundary with no schools, churches, other commercial operations or government owned facilities within 1.5 miles of the facility.
The facility has developed and tested the SO2 cylinder handling and SO2 gas application system standard operating procedures.  The adherence to these procedures makes any release very unlikely.  There have never been more than a few pounds of SO2 released since placed in service at the plant.  These minor releases result from cyl

inder change over.  The facility has never experienced a release of five hundred (500) pounds or more of SO2.
An in plant response program has been prepared to provide the maximum effective impact in the least amount of time:
         1.  Use the plant intercom to report a suspected release
         2.  Trained and properly equipped maintenance personnel access the release
         3.   If release of >10 pounds has occurred, dial 911.  The Bridgeport/Taylor Co. Emergency Services offices will perform community notification for shelter in place or evacuation.
4. Utilizing established safe operating procedures to isolate the release point on the cylinder or related piping AFG personnel will attempt to perform the isolation.
5.   If AFG is not successful in isolating the release point, the sulfur dioxide supplier will perform the isolation/repair.
